Key areas of interest include the development of medications, precision medicine approaches, behavioral therapies, mechanisms of behavioral change, recovery processes, translational research, and innovative methods and technologies for AUD treatment.

title: Innovative Screening Approaches and Therapies for Screenable Disorders in Newborns (R01 - Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on developing innovative screening methods and therapeutic interventions for serious conditions identified through newborn screening, as well as for high-priority genetic conditions that may soon be eligible for screening. Key research topics include the creation of accurate screening tests and the demonstration of the benefits of early intervention or treatment for these conditions.

title: Innovative Screening Approaches and Therapies for Screenable Disorders in Newborns (R21 - Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on developing innovative screening methods and therapeutic interventions for serious conditions identified through newborn screening, as well as for high-priority genetic conditions that may soon be eligible for screening. Key research topics include the creation of accurate screening tests and demonstrating the advantages of early intervention or treatment for these conditions.

title: NCCIH Natural Product Mid Phase Clinical Trial (R01 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on mid-phase clinical trials of natural products, including botanicals, dietary supplements, and probiotics, with a strong scientific basis for further testing. Key research topics include optimizing doses or formulations of these natural products and identifying patient phenotypes that respond to them, supported by preliminary data on bioavailability and target engagement. The trials must be hypothesis-driven and aligned with the research priorities of the NCCIH, excluding cancer-related studies.

title: NCCIH Natural Product Early Phase Clinical Trial Award (R33 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on early phase clinical trials of natural products, including botanicals, dietary supplements, and probiotics, with a strong scientific basis for further testing. Key research topics include the standardization of nutritional compounds, optimization of delivery methods, and the exploration of combinations with other treatments to enhance target engagement and clinical outcomes. The aim is to translate basic science findings into clinical applications, providing valuable insights for future research directions.

title: Targeting Cell Surface HIV Envelope for Cell Elimination (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on research related to HIV-1 Envelope (Env) cell surface expression, the mechanisms by which biologics induce cell death, and innovative strategies to improve the detection and destruction of HIV-1 infected cells expressing Env. The ultimate goal is to advance immunotherapy and vaccine development for the prevention and cure of HIV-1.

title: NCCIH Natural Product Early Phase Clinical Trial Phased Innovation Award (R61/R33 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on early phase clinical trials of natural products, including botanicals, probiotics, and dietary supplements, with a strong scientific basis for further testing. Key research topics include pharmacokinetics, bioavailability, and the mechanisms of action of these natural products, as well as optimizing their delivery and assessing their impact on specific target measures and clinical outcomes in human populations. Applications may also explore combinations of natural products with other treatments to enhance efficacy.

title: Accelerating Solutions to Improve Access and Quality of Empirically-Supported Practices for Youth Mental Health (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on research aimed at improving access to evidence-based mental health interventions for youth, particularly in underserved areas such as rural communities and inner cities. Key topics include optimizing assessment and intervention strategies, addressing workforce shortages, integrating mental health services into various settings (like schools and social services), and tackling systemic barriers to mental health care access and quality.

title: Mobile Health: Technology and Outcomes in Low and Middle Income Countries (R21/R33 - Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on exploratory research into innovative mobile health (mHealth) interventions tailored for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Key areas of interest include the development, validation, and effectiveness of mHealth tools that leverage new technologies and analytics to enhance clinical and public health outcomes, while also building research capacity in these regions. Collaborative partnerships between U.S. and LMIC institutions are essential for the proposed projects.

title: NHLBI Early Phase Clinical Trials for Therapeutics and/or Diagnostics for HLBS Disorders (R61/R33 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on supporting Phase I clinical trials for diagnostic and therapeutic interventions targeting heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) disorders in both adults and children. It emphasizes the need for final stage preclinical activities that are directly related to the proposed trials, which can be conducted at single or multiple sites.

title: NHLBI Early Phase Clinical Trials for Therapeutics and/or Diagnostics for HLBS Disorders (R33 CT Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on supporting phase I clinical trials aimed at developing diagnostic and therapeutic interventions for heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) disorders in both adults and children. The trials can be conducted at single or multiple sites, and applicants must be prepared to initiate the trials promptly after receiving funding.

title: Interventions to Address Disparities in Liver Diseases and Liver Cancer (R01 - Clinical Trials Optional)
summary_text: This initiative focuses on multi-level and multi-domain intervention research aimed at reducing disparities in liver diseases and liver cancer among populations in the U.S. that experience health disparities. The research should address the underlying factors contributing to these disparities and explore effective strategies for intervention.

title: Accelerating the Pace of Substance Use Research Using Existing Data (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on the innovative analysis of existing social science, behavioral, administrative, and neuroimaging data to investigate the etiology and epidemiology of drug use behaviors, including alcohol, tobacco, and prescription drugs. Key research topics include the prevention of drug use and HIV, health service utilization, and the development of effective strategies for the prevention and treatment of drug abuse and related disorders. The aim is to enhance understanding of the trajectories of drug use behaviors, their consequences, and the factors influencing risk and resilience in psychopathology.

title: Accelerating the Pace of Substance Use Research Using Existing Data (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on the innovative analysis of existing social science, behavioral, administrative, and neuroimaging data to investigate the etiology and epidemiology of drug use behaviors, including alcohol, tobacco, and prescription drugs. It aims to enhance understanding of the consequences of these behaviors, such as morbidity and mortality, and to develop effective prevention and treatment strategies for drug abuse and HIV.

title: Pilot Health Services and Economic Research on the Treatment of Drug, Alcohol, and Tobacco Use Disorders (R34 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on pilot and preliminary research aimed at optimizing access to and the effectiveness of treatments for drug, tobacco, and alcohol use disorders, as well as services for comorbid medical and mental health conditions. It encourages the testing of both novel and commonly used interventions, practices, and policies, with an emphasis on assessing their feasibility, acceptability, and utility in preparation for larger-scale effectiveness trials.

title: Interventions to Reduce Sleep Health Disparities (R01 - Clinical Trials Optional)
summary_text: The key research topics for this funding opportunity include the development and evaluation of non-pharmacological interventions aimed at promoting sleep health and addressing sleep health disparities. Additionally, the focus is on investigating sleep as a modifiable factor that can help reduce health disparities in various health outcomes among affected populations.

title: Preclinical Proof of Concept Studies for Rare Diseases (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The key research topics focus on conducting efficacy studies in established preclinical models for rare diseases, evaluating therapeutic agents such as small molecules and biologics. The scientific focus areas include pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic studies to support the development of these agents, with the ultimate goal of advancing projects towards full Investigational New Drug (IND) application or clinical trials.

title: Role of Defective Proviruses in HIV Persistence (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on research aimed at understanding the role of defective HIV proviruses in HIV persistence and pathogenesis during antiretroviral treatment. It also seeks to explore how these defective proviruses may negatively affect HIV cure strategies and interfere with HIV-specific molecular assays.

title: Clinical Observational (CO) Studies in Musculoskeletal, Rheumatic, and Skin Diseases (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The key research topics for this grant call focus on clinical observational studies related to musculoskeletal, rheumatic, and skin diseases. The scientific emphasis is on understanding these conditions through observational research methodologies.

title: BRAIN Initiative: New Concepts and Early-Stage Research for Recording and Modulation in the Nervous System (R21) (Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The BRAIN Initiative aims to advance understanding of how neural circuits encode information through electrical and chemical signals, influencing sensations, thoughts, emotions, and actions. This grant call focuses on developing innovative technologies in the early stages of conceptualization for large-scale recording or manipulation of neural activity, as well as supporting computational models and experimental approaches to validate theoretical assumptions. Key research topics include novel measurement technologies, mathematical techniques, and the creation of prototypes or models for future testing in animal models.

title: Awards Supporting Cutting-Edge Technologies for Translational Science (ASCETTS) (R21 Clinical Trials Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NCATS is seeking applications for innovative technology development aimed at overcoming challenges in translational science, particularly in therapeutic development. The focus is on early-stage, high-risk studies that explore new technologies or novel applications to enhance the efficiency of the therapeutic development pipeline.

title: Exploratory/Developmental Bioengineering Research Grants (EBRG) (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) is seeking exploratory and developmental research proposals in bioengineering that focus on enhancing the quality, speed, efficacy, operability, cost-effectiveness, and accessibility of solutions in biomedical research, clinical care delivery, and related areas. Key research topics include the development of new capabilities and improvements in existing technologies to address challenges in basic, pre-clinical, and clinical settings.

title: HEAL Initiative-Early-Stage Discovery of New Pain Targets Within the Understudied Druggable Proteome (R03 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on pilot projects aimed at identifying new druggable targets for pain within the understudied druggable proteome. It encourages research on understudied proteins related to pain and pain management, supporting the generation of preliminary data and tools to characterize these proteins. The initiative is part of the NIH HEAL initiative, which seeks to develop novel medications addressing various aspects of opioid addiction and its consequences.

title: Exploratory/Developmental Bioengineering Research Grants (EBRG) (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) is seeking exploratory and developmental research proposals in bioengineering that focus on enhancing the quality, speed, efficacy, operability, cost-effectiveness, and accessibility of solutions in biomedical research, clinical care delivery, and related areas. Key research topics include the development of new capabilities and improvements in existing technologies to address challenges in basic, pre-clinical, and clinical settings.

title: Single-Site Investigator-Initiated Clinical Trials (R61/R33 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on developing and implementing investigator-initiated single site clinical trials, including efficacy, comparative effectiveness, pragmatic, and implementation research. The trials may explore various therapeutic, behavioral, and prevention strategies relevant to the NHLBI's research mission. Applicants are expected to provide a scientific rationale and a detailed operational plan for the trial, addressing aspects such as project management and subject recruitment.

title: Limited Competition: Small Grant Program for the NCATS Clinical and Translational Science Award (CTSA) Program (R03 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This NOFO focuses on enhancing the research capabilities of NCATS CTSA Program KL2 scholars and re-entry supplement recipients in clinical and translational science. Key research topics include pilot and feasibility studies, secondary data analysis, small self-contained projects, research methodology development, and new research technology, with an emphasis on projects that can be completed quickly and with limited resources.

title: Risk and Protective Factors of Family Health and Family Level Interventions (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This initiative focuses on advancing the science of minority health and health disparities, specifically through research on family health, family well-being, and family resilience. The aim is to decrease disparities and promote equity in these critical areas.

title: D-START: Data Science Track Award for Research Transition (D/START) (R03-Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The grant call focuses on advancing addiction-related data science by encouraging both new and established researchers to apply innovative data science methodologies to critical questions in the field. It emphasizes the use of existing datasets, adherence to FAIR principles, and ethical considerations in research involving human subjects. The goal is to develop preliminary projects that can lead to larger-scale research initiatives at the intersection of data science and addiction studies.

title: Limited Competition: Small Grant Program for NHLBI K01/K08/K23/K25 Recipients (R03 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity invites NHLBI K01, K08, K23, and K25 awardees to apply for small grants to expand their research or pursue new studies stemming from their K award research. Key focus areas include pilot or feasibility studies, proof of concept studies, secondary data analysis, and the development of new methodologies or experimental models, with an emphasis on generating preliminary data for future R01 applications. Additionally, the research may involve patient-oriented studies, particularly for K23 awardees.

title: NIDCD Research Grants for Translating Basic Research into Clinical Practice (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on translational research that bridges basic scientific discoveries with clinical applications aimed at improving human health, specifically in the area of communication disorders. Key research topics include the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of these disorders, with an emphasis on establishing clear connections to clinical conditions and achieving practical clinical outcomes.

title: Toward Translation of Nanotechnology Cancer Interventions (TTNCI; R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The key research topics for the "Toward Translation of Nanotechnology Cancer Interventions" (TTNCI) include advanced pre-clinical research focused on the development of nanotechnology-based cancer diagnostics and therapeutics. The scientific focus areas emphasize the maturation of experimental nanomedicines utilizing nanoparticles and nano-devices to enhance cancer treatment effectiveness through innovative structural designs and therapeutic or diagnostic delivery systems.

title: Supporting Talented Early Career Researchers in Genomics (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The grant call focuses on supporting innovative research in genomics, specifically in areas such as genomic sciences, genomic medicine, genomic data science, and the ethical, legal, and social implications of genomics. It aims to foster the careers of Early Stage Investigators committed to advancing these fields.

title: NIH Small Research Grant Program (Parent R03 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NIH Small Research Grant Program focuses on supporting small-scale research projects, including pilot and feasibility studies, secondary data analysis, and the development of research methodologies and technologies. It emphasizes projects that can be completed quickly and with limited resources, while excluding clinical trial proposals.

title: NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Project Grant (Parent R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NIH Exploratory/Developmental Grant focuses on supporting innovative and high-risk research projects in biomedical, behavioral, and clinical fields. Key areas of interest include the development of novel techniques, methodologies, agents, and models that have the potential to lead to significant breakthroughs and advancements in research.

title: NHLBI Clinical Trial Pilot Studies (R34 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on research that informs the planning of Phase II-IV clinical trials related to heart, lung, blood, and sleep disorders. It aims to support studies that provide necessary and sufficient data to design or plan these trials, specifically targeting the efficacy, safety, clinical management, or implementation of interventions for these conditions. The research should address scientific or operational questions that will aid in the final development of the subsequent clinical trials.

title: NIH Research Project Grant (Parent R01 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: The NIH Research Project Grant focuses on discrete research projects that align with the specific interests and competencies of the investigators. Key areas of interest include clinical trials and research that corresponds with the scientific missions of participating NIH Institutes and Centers.

title: NIH Research Project Grant (Parent R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NIH Research Project Grant focuses on discrete research projects aligned with the specific interests and competencies of the investigators. Proposed projects should relate to the scientific missions of participating NIH Institutes and Centers, excluding clinical trial applications.

title: NIH Research Project Grant (Parent R01 Basic Experimental Studies with Humans Required)
summary_text: The NIH Research Project Grant focuses on basic science experimental studies involving human participants, specifically those that prospectively assign individuals to conditions to assess biomedical or behavioral outcomes. The aim is to understand fundamental phenomena without immediate application towards processes or products. Research proposals must align with the scientific missions of participating NIH Institutes and Centers.

title: NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Project Grant (Parent R21 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: The NIH Exploratory/Developmental Grant focuses on supporting innovative and high-risk research projects in biomedical, behavioral, or clinical fields. Key areas of interest include the development of novel techniques, methodologies, and applications, with a requirement for at least one clinical trial to be included in the proposed research. The projects should align with the scientific missions of participating NIH Institutes and Centers.

title: NIH Exploratory/Developmental Research Project Grant (Parent R21 Basic Experimental Studies with Humans Required)
summary_text: The NIH Exploratory/Developmental Grant focuses on supporting innovative research projects in the early stages that may involve significant risk but have the potential for breakthroughs in biomedical, behavioral, or clinical research. Key research topics include basic science experimental studies involving human participants, particularly those that prospectively assign participants to conditions to assess biomedical or behavioral outcomes, aimed at understanding fundamental phenomena without immediate application in mind.

title: Elucidating Immunometabolic Responses to HIV Infection that Increase TB or HBV Risk (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on research investigating the immunometabolic changes induced by HIV in individuals on combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). It aims to understand how these alterations affect immune responses, cell regulation, and interactions, particularly in relation to the risk of secondary infections like Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) and hepatitis B virus (HBV), as well as their impact on disease progression.

title: Elucidating Immunometabolic Responses to HIV Infection that Increase TB or HBV Risk (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on researching the immunometabolic changes induced by HIV in individuals on combination antiretroviral therapy and how these changes affect immune responses. Key areas of interest include the impact of HIV-driven immunometabolic alterations on immune cell regulation, interactions, treatment responses, and the progression of secondary infections such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Hepatitis B Virus.

title: Cutting-Edge Basic Research Awards (CEBRA) (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The NIDA Cutting-Edge Basic Research Award (CEBRA) focuses on innovative research related to the etiology, pathophysiology, prevention, and treatment of substance use disorders (SUDs). It encourages the development of revolutionary techniques and methods for addiction research, as well as the testing of significant hypotheses that have limited existing data but could fundamentally change the understanding of SUDs.

title: Translational Bioinformatics and Experimental Approaches to Advance Drug Repositioning and Combination Therapy Development for Alzheimers Disease and Related Dementias (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on using mouse models for preclinical testing of existing and investigational drugs aimed at treating Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (ADRD). It emphasizes the evaluation of drug combinations and the integration of non-pharmacologic interventions to enhance translational outcomes, with the ultimate goal of establishing proof of concept for drug repurposing and combination therapy development.

title: Early Immune System Development and Ontogeny (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on understanding the mechanisms of early immune development in utero and during early childhood, particularly in relation to HIV exposure and Anti-Retroviral Therapeutics (ART). Key research topics include the maternal-fetal immune interface, T and B cell development and maturation in offspring, and the interplay between local and systemic immune responses.

title: Secondary Analysis of Existing Datasets in Heart, Lung, and Blood Diseases and Sleep Disorders (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on utilizing existing human datasets for secondary analyses to explore innovative scientific concepts or develop new models, systems, tools, methods, or technologies. The aim is to enhance biomedical or biobehavioral research aligned with the NHLBI mission.

title: Planning for Product Development Strategy (R34 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on developing next-generation treatments for HIV, including strategies for managing HIV-associated comorbidities, coinfections, and complications. It aims to facilitate the translation of research findings into drug products suitable for FDA Investigational New Drug (IND) applications.

title: Innovative Pilot Mental Health Services Research Not Involving Clinical Trials (R34 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding announcement encourages pilot research in services that align with NIMH priorities, focusing on areas of services research that do not necessarily lead to clinical trials. The emphasis is on exploring innovative approaches and methodologies in mental health services that contribute to the understanding and improvement of mental health care delivery.

title: Innovative Mental Health Services Research Not Involving Clinical Trials (R01 Clinical Trials Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding announcement focuses on innovative research aimed at enhancing the delivery of high-quality mental health services for individuals with or at risk of mental illness. It specifically invites non-clinical trial R01-level projects that align with the NIMH's strategic priorities in mental health services research.

title: Academic-Industrial Partnerships for Translation of Technologies for Diagnosis and Treatment (R01 - Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) is focusing on translating scientific discoveries and engineering advancements into practical methods or tools aimed at understanding diseases and improving applied research. Key research topics include assessing risk, detecting, preventing, diagnosing, treating, and managing diseases, with an emphasis on developing new technologies and methods for pre-clinical, clinical, and non-clinical settings.

title: Academic-Industrial Partnerships for Translation of Technologies for Diagnosis and Treatment (R01 - Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The key research topics focus on translating scientific discoveries and engineering developments into practical methods or tools for understanding disease and improving applied research in areas such as risk assessment, detection, prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and disease management. The initiative aims to enhance technologies and methods that support research and healthcare delivery across various settings, addressing conditions and diseases relevant to the missions of the participating institutes.

title: NEI Research Grant for Vision-Related Secondary Data Analysis (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on vision-related research projects that utilize secondary data analyses from existing databases. It also encourages the development of statistical methodologies aimed at enhancing the analysis of vision health data.

title: In Vivo High-Resolution Imaging for Inner Ear Visualization (R01 Clinical Trial optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on advancing in vivo high-resolution imaging technologies for the human inner ear, emphasizing the development of techniques that enhance the visualization of inner ear structures with greater detail and accuracy. Key research topics include improving existing imaging methods, creating new imaging probes or contrast agents, and visualizing both structural and functional elements of the inner ear, such as hair cells and vasculature, in awake patients. Collaborative, multi-disciplinary approaches are encouraged, with studies permitted in humans and relevant animal models.

title: Multidisciplinary Studies of HIV/AIDS and Aging (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on research at the intersection of HIV and aging, specifically aiming to enhance understanding of the biological, clinical, and socio-behavioral aspects of aging in the context of HIV infection and treatment. Additionally, it seeks to improve strategies for testing, preventing, and treating HIV, as well as managing related comorbidities and complications across diverse populations and cultural settings, utilizing current aging science methodologies.

title: Advancing HIV/AIDS Research within the Mission of the NIDCD (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on stimulating HIV/AIDS research related to the areas of hearing, balance, taste, smell, voice, speech, and language, as outlined by the NIH Office of AIDS Research. It encourages applications that address high-priority research topics within these domains, particularly those that may involve low-risk clinical trials.

title: Multidisciplinary Studies of HIV/AIDS and Aging (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on research that explores the intersection of HIV and aging, specifically aiming to enhance understanding of the biological, clinical, and socio-behavioral aspects of aging in the context of HIV infection and treatment. Additionally, it seeks to improve strategies for testing, preventing, and treating HIV, as well as managing related comorbidities and complications across diverse populations and cultural settings, utilizing current aging science methodologies.

title: Trailblazer Award for New and Early Stage Investigators (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The Trailblazer Award focuses on research that integrates engineering and physical sciences with life and biomedical sciences. It encourages exploratory, developmental, and high-risk projects that may be technology design-directed, discovery-driven, or hypothesis-driven, with an emphasis on innovative approaches that do not require preliminary data.

title: Joint NINDS/NIMH Exploratory Neuroscience Research Grant (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The Joint NINDS/NIMH Exploratory Neuroscience Research Grant program focuses on innovative and exploratory research in neuroscience, particularly in understanding neurological and mental health disorders. Key areas of interest include the feasibility of novel investigative approaches, the development of new techniques and methodologies, and mechanistic clinical trials or basic experimental studies involving human subjects.

title: Unveiling Health and Healthcare Disparities in Non-Communicable and Chronic Diseases in Latin America: Setting the Stage for Better Health Outcomes Across the Hemisphere (R01 - Clinical Trials Not Allowed)
summary_text: The key research topics for this funding opportunity include clinical epidemiology, evaluation of public and health care policies, and validation of measurements related to health disparities. The focus is on non-communicable and chronic diseases with significant impact in Latin America and among U.S. Hispanics/Latinos, emphasizing collaborative, multi-disciplinary approaches.

title: Priority HIV/AIDS Research within the Mission of NIDDK (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on advancing HIV/AIDS research that aligns with the priorities set by the NIH Office of AIDS Research. Key research topics include the intersection of HIV/AIDS with diabetes, digestive diseases, and kidney diseases, emphasizing innovative approaches to understanding and addressing these health challenges.

title: Advancing HIV/AIDS Research within the Mission of the NIDCD (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on stimulating HIV/AIDS research related to the scientific areas of hearing, balance, taste, smell, voice, speech, and language. It encourages applications that align with the high-priority research topics identified by the NIH Office of AIDS Research, particularly in the context of these communication disorders. Additionally, it supports low-risk clinical trials in this domain.

title: Pilot Studies of Biological, Behavioral and Social Mechanisms Contributing to HIV Pathogenesis Within the Mission of NIDDK (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on innovative basic and translational research related to HIV/AIDS, particularly in understanding the pathophysiological mechanisms of HIV comorbidities, coinfections, and complications affecting various organs and tissues. It also emphasizes the investigation of biological mechanisms behind HIV reservoirs in NIDDK-relevant tissues to inform strategies for viral suppression or eradication, as well as the impact of social determinants of health on these issues.

title: Development and Testing of Novel Interventions to Improve HIV Prevention, Treatment, and Program Implementation for People Who Use Substances (R34 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity emphasizes formative research and the development of interventions aimed at HIV prevention and treatment for people who use drugs. Key focus areas include assessing the feasibility, tolerability, acceptability, and safety of novel or adapted interventions, which may encompass behavioral, social, structural, and combination biomedical approaches.

title: Small R01s for Clinical Trials Targeting Diseases within the Mission of NIDDK (R01 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding announcement focuses on supporting pilot and feasibility clinical trials in humans aimed at the prevention and treatment of diseases under the NIDDK's mission. The trials should gather preliminary data on intervention effects, recruitment, retention, and study conduct, with the goal of paving the way for larger, more definitive trials that enhance understanding and improve clinical practice or public health.

title: Limited Competition: Small Grant Program for NIDDK K01/K08/K23/K25 Recipients (R03 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: The NIDDK is focusing on enhancing the research capabilities of K01, K08, K23, and K25 award recipients through Small Grant (R03) support. Key research topics include pilot and feasibility studies, secondary data analysis, small self-contained projects, and the development of research methodologies and technologies, all aimed at facilitating the transition to independent investigator status.

title: NEI Clinical Research Study Planning Grant Program (R34 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NEI grant call focuses on supporting large-scale clinical vision research projects, specifically randomized clinical trials and epidemiologic studies related to eye and vision conditions. Key research topics include the development of study protocols and Manuals of Procedures (MOP), as well as conducting preliminary studies to refine procedures and assess recruitment potential, without generating data on intervention effects.

title: Interventions on Health and Healthcare Disparities on Non-Communicable and Chronic Diseases in Latin America: Improving Health Outcomes Across the Hemisphere (R01 - Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: This funding opportunity aims to support interdisciplinary research teams investigating clinical, health services, and community-based interventions targeting health and healthcare disparities associated with non-communicable and chronic diseases in Latin America and among U.S. Hispanics/Latinos. The focus is on addressing the highest burden and mortality rates of these diseases through meaningful collaboration with partners from Latin American institutions.

title: Ethical, Legal and Social Implications (ELSI) Research (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call invites research proposals focused on the ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI) of human genetics and genomics. It encourages the use of various research methods, including qualitative and quantitative approaches, as well as conceptual and legal analyses, with an emphasis on stakeholder involvement.

title: Ethical, Legal and Social Implications (ELSI) Exploratory/Developmental Research Grant (R21 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This grant call focuses on exploratory and developmental research into the ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI) of human genetics and genomics. Key research topics include the study of new or emerging genomic technologies and novel uses of genomic information, utilizing various methodologies such as qualitative and quantitative research, as well as conceptual and legal analyses. Involvement of relevant stakeholders in the research process is encouraged.

title: Ethical, Legal and Social Implications (ELSI) Small Research Grant (R03 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity invites research proposals that investigate the ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI) of human genetics and genomics. Key focus areas include normative and conceptual analyses across various disciplines such as law, economics, philosophy, anthropology, and history, particularly concerning new or emerging issues in the field. Additionally, projects may involve preliminary data collection or secondary analysis of existing data.

title: Collaborative Research Using Biosamples and/or Data from Type 1 Diabetes Clinical Studies (R01 - Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on research into the etiology and pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes, utilizing data and samples from clinical trials and studies. It aims to support collaborative investigative teams in exploring disease mechanisms to enhance prevention strategies for type 1 diabetes.

title: Intervention Research to Improve Native American Health (R34 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on research aimed at improving health in Native American populations through several key areas: etiologic research to inform intervention development, the development and testing of health promotion and disease prevention interventions, culturally informed treatment and recovery strategies, and dissemination and implementation research to enhance the adoption and sustainability of effective interventions. The initiative emphasizes leveraging community strengths and resilience while addressing the unique sociopolitical and environmental challenges faced by these populations.

title: Intervention Research to Improve Native American Health (R01 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: It seems there is no grant call description provided. Please share the details of the grant call, and I will help you extract and summarize the key research topics and scientific focus areas.

title: New Investigator Gateway Awards for Collaborative T1D Research (R03 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The New Investigator Gateway Award in T1D Research focuses on supporting innovative projects and new investigators in Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) research. Key research topics include preliminary studies that address critical questions in T1D, fostering collaboration within established scientific consortia, and enhancing networking opportunities for early-stage researchers.

title: Stephen I. Katz Early Stage Investigator Research Project Grant (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The grant focuses on supporting innovative research projects led by early stage investigators that represent a significant shift in their research direction. It emphasizes the exploration of new ideas or approaches without the requirement for preliminary data.

title: Stephen I. Katz Early Stage Investigator Research Project Grant (R01 Basic Experimental Studies with Human Required)
summary_text: The Stephen I. Katz Early Stage Investigator Research Project Grant focuses on innovative basic science experimental studies involving human participants, particularly those that prospectively assign individuals to conditions to assess biomedical or behavioral outcomes. The research must represent a significant change in direction for early stage investigators and should not include preliminary data, emphasizing fundamental understanding rather than specific applications.

title: Tobacco Regulatory Science Small Grant Program for New Investigators (R03 Clinical Trial Optional)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on supporting early-career researchers in tobacco regulatory research, emphasizing projects that can inform FDA regulations on tobacco product manufacturing, distribution, and marketing. Key research topics include pilot studies, secondary data analysis, and the development of research methodologies and technologies related to tobacco control as mandated by the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act. The goal is to generate findings that directly impact public health through effective tobacco regulation.

title: BRAIN Initiative: Theories, Models and Methods for Analysis of Complex Data from the Brain (R01 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The TMM initiative focuses on developing computational tools to enhance understanding of dynamic brain circuits, emphasizing theories of neural mechanisms, models of circuit structure and function, and computational analysis methods. Key research topics include characterizing brain function principles, cellular and circuit-level computations, and the interactions of multiple brain circuits that influence behavior and neural dynamics. The initiative aims to facilitate advancements in treatments for brain disorders like Parkinson's disease and major depressive disorder.

title: Native American Research Centers for Health (NARCH) Planning Grants (R34 - Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: The NARCH Planning Grants program focuses on supporting research initiatives that address health issues pertinent to federally recognized American Indian and Alaska Native Tribes. Key areas of interest include health disparities, community health needs, and the development of research capacity within Tribal entities.

title: Mind and Body Interventions to Restore Whole Person Health via Emotional Well-Being Mechanisms (R61/R33 Clinical Trial Required)
summary_text: The NCCIH is seeking research applications focused on the effects of mind and body interventions, such as mindfulness meditation, yoga, and acupuncture, on emotional well-being (EWB) and its relationship with whole person health (WPH). The initiative aims to support mechanistic studies that explore innovative mechanisms of EWB as the primary outcome, with the Whole Person Health Index as a secondary outcome, emphasizing the need for strong preliminary data.

title: Expanding the Target Landscape by Drugging the Undruggable (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity seeks exploratory and early-stage research projects aimed at addressing undruggable target classes associated with intractable human diseases. The focus is on developing innovative methods or agents that selectively target these challenging classes, advancing strategies that cannot be tackled by conventional therapies.

title: Advancing Research on the Application of Digital Health Technology to the Management of Type 2 Diabetes (R01- Clinical Trail Required)
summary_text: The key research topics focus on evaluating the efficacy and clinical effectiveness of multimodal digital health technologies for the remote management of diabetes. The emphasis is on innovative approaches that integrate various digital tools to enhance diabetes care and patient outcomes.

title: Clinical Trial Readiness for Rare Diseases, Disorders, and Syndromes (R21 Clinical Trial Not Allowed)
summary_text: This funding opportunity focuses on advancing clinical trial readiness for rare diseases by supporting projects that enhance the development and testing of biomarkers and clinical outcome assessments. It aims to facilitate the progression of candidate therapeutics and diagnostics toward clinical trials, thereby increasing their chances of success. Additionally, it encourages research that defines the presentation and course of rare diseases to inform the design of future clinical trials.

title: Chemical Oceanography
summary_text: The Chemical Oceanography Program focuses on the chemistry of oceans and their role in global geochemical cycles. Key research topics include the chemical composition and transformation of oceanic substances, chemical exchanges between oceans and the Earth system, internal cycling within marine environments, and the use of chemical distributions to indicate various physical, biological, and geological processes.

title: Computational Mathematics
summary_text: The grant call focuses on mathematical research that emphasizes the role of computation, particularly in the analysis, development, and implementation of efficient algorithms. It encourages proposals that create and analyze new computational mathematics techniques, as well as their application to significant problems, while also promoting the training of junior computational mathematicians through research involvement.

title: Foundations
summary_text: The Foundations program supports research in mathematical logic and the foundations of mathematics, focusing on areas such as proof theory, recursion theory, model theory, set theory, and infinitary combinatorics. It also encourages the organization of conferences, workshops, and educational activities related to these topics.

title: Combinatorics
summary_text: The Combinatorics program focuses on research in discrete structures, encompassing various areas such as algebraic, enumerative, existential, extremal, geometric, and probabilistic combinatorics, with a particular emphasis on graph theory.

title: Ocean Technology and Interdisciplinary Coordination
summary_text: The OTIC Program focuses on research and technology development in ocean science, particularly in instrumentation that enhances observational, experimental, or analytical capabilities. It also invites proposals for projects aimed at improving facilities, communications, and equipment at biological field stations and marine laboratories, as well as initiatives under the National Ocean Partnership Program.

title: Linguistics
summary_text: The Linguistics Program focuses on basic research in human language, covering areas such as syntax, semantics, morphology, phonetics, and phonology. Key research topics include the psychological processes of language production and comprehension, the computational properties of language, the relationship between speech properties and language theories, the influence of neurobiology on grammar, language development across the lifespan, and the social and cultural factors affecting language variation and change. The program also emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches and supports research on understudied and endangered languages.

title: Perception, Action & Cognition
summary_text: The PAC program focuses on research related to human perceptual, motor, and cognitive processes, emphasizing their interactions and real-world applications. It encourages diverse methodologies, including computational modeling, and aims to produce knowledge that benefits society. Proposals should explore human behavior in realistic scenarios and involve varied subject populations, while avoiding purely neural or clinical studies without direct relevance to human cognition.

title: Science of Learning and Augmented Intelligence (SL)
summary_text: The Science of Learning and Augmented Intelligence (SL) program focuses on transformative research into the principles and mechanisms of learning, both in individuals and groups, and how human cognitive functions can be enhanced through technology and social interactions. Key research topics include the underlying mechanisms of learning transfer, the interplay between individual and collaborative learning processes, the impact of artificial intelligence on human task performance, and the integration of insights across various levels of analysisâ€”from molecular mechanisms to cognitive and social processes. The program encourages interdisciplinary approaches and seeks to explore how biological learning can inform advancements in artificial intelligence and technology design.

title: Analysis
summary_text: The Analysis Program focuses on research in various areas of analysis, including complex, harmonic, and real analysis, as well as dynamical systems and ergodic theory. Additional key topics include functional analysis, mathematical physics, operator theory and operator algebras, and partial differential equations with calculus of variations.

title: Mathematical Sciences Infrastructure Program
summary_text: The Mathematical Sciences Infrastructure Program focuses on enhancing the research infrastructure within the mathematical sciences community, promoting interdisciplinary collaborations, and supporting training initiatives that prepare individuals for careers in this field. Key research topics include the development of novel projects that strengthen research infrastructure, training projects with a core research component, and support for conferences and workshops that address broad mathematical themes and have national significance. The program emphasizes regional and national impact, broadening participation, and professional development for students and early career researchers.

title: Algebra and Number Theory
summary_text: The key research topics supported by the Algebra and Number Theory program include algebra, algebraic and arithmetic geometry, number theory, and representation theory. The program also encourages the organization of conferences, workshops, and educational activities related to these areas.

title: Algorithms for Modern Power Systems
summary_text: The Algorithms for Modern Power Systems (AMPS) program focuses on advancing mathematical and statistical algorithms aimed at enhancing the security, reliability, and efficiency of modern power grids. It encourages research that integrates mathematical sciences with energy delivery and reliability challenges.

title: Geometric Analysis
summary_text: The Geometric Analysis program focuses on research in differential geometry, its connections to partial differential equations and variational principles, and geometric methods in mathematical physics. Key areas of interest include symplectic geometry, geometric group theory, geometric data analysis, and various aspects of global analysis such as convex, complex, integral, and information geometries.

title: Topology
summary_text: The Topology program focuses on research in various areas of algebraic topology, including chromatic, equivariant, motivic, and (un)stable homotopy, as well as homology and cohomology theories. Key topics also include bordism, K-theory, topological manifolds, knots and links, geometric and differential topology, transformation groups, topological quantum field theories, and topological data analysis.

title: Joint DMS/NIGMS Initiative to Support Research at the Interface of the Biological and Mathematical Sciences
summary_text: The grant call focuses on fundamental research in mathematics and statistics that addresses questions in the biological and biomedical sciences, emphasizing the interface between mathematical and life sciences. It aims to foster new collaborations and support innovative activities among existing research teams.

title: Mathematical Biology
summary_text: The Mathematical Biology Program focuses on research that integrates mathematical sciences with biological sciences, emphasizing mathematical innovation and biological significance. Key areas of interest include the development of mathematical theories, methodologies, and tools that can enhance understanding and applications in biological contexts. Proposals that demonstrate strong collaboration between mathematics and biology are particularly encouraged.

title: Astronomy and Astrophysics Research Grants
summary_text: The Astronomy and Astrophysics Research Grants (AAG) Program focuses on supporting research in the astronomical sciences, including observational, theoretical, laboratory, and archival data studies. It encourages proposals that may involve interdisciplinary approaches and the development of tools that enhance astronomical research.

title: Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation for the Astronomical Sciences
summary_text: The ATI program focuses on the development of innovative technologies and instrumentation for ground-based astronomy and astrophysics. Key research topics include advanced technology development, concept feasibility studies, and specialized instrumentation aimed at enabling new astronomical observations that are currently challenging or unachievable with existing methods. Proposals may involve hardware, software development, or analysis to facilitate these new observational capabilities.

title: Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Directorate for STEM Education
summary_text: The NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) initiative focuses on enhancing undergraduate STEM education through innovative and evidence-based teaching practices. Key research topics include the integration of recent STEM advances into curricula, the adaptation of effective pedagogical techniques, and the promotion of diversity within STEM fields. The program also emphasizes the importance of institutional partnerships and aims to generate knowledge that improves STEM learning environments and prepares students for the workforce.

title: Social Psychology
summary_text: The Social Psychology Program at NSF focuses on empirical research that enhances understanding of how social forces influence human behavior, attitudes, and experiences. Key research topics include the interplay of thought, motivation, emotion, and physiological processes in shaping social dynamics, as well as the development of new theories and methods. Proposals that address global challenges and promote open science practices are particularly encouraged, with an emphasis on interdisciplinary approaches and the potential for societal benefits.

title: Biological Oceanography
summary_text: The Biological Oceanography Program focuses on fundamental research in biological oceanography and marine ecology across various environments, including estuarine, coastal, open ocean, deep sea, and Great Lakes ecosystems. Key research topics include population, community, and ecosystem ecology, with an emphasis on interdisciplinary approaches that enhance the understanding of marine and Great Lakes ecosystems.

title: A Science of Science Approach to Analyzing and Innovating the Biomedical Research Enterprise
summary_text: The NSF and NIH are seeking proposals that enhance understanding of the biomedical research enterprise through the lens of science policy research. Key focus areas include the dynamics of human behavior and social organizations, the impact of various forces on individuals throughout their lives, and the scientific basis of science and innovation policy. The collaboration aims to foster a diverse and efficient scientific workforce while advancing basic biomedical research that informs disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

title: Decision, Risk and Management Sciences
summary_text: The Decision, Risk and Management Sciences Program (DRMS) focuses on enhancing the understanding and effectiveness of decision-making processes across various levels, including individuals, groups, organizations, and society. Key research topics include judgment and decision making, decision analysis and aids, risk analysis and communication, societal and public-policy decision making, and management science and organizational design. The program encourages both disciplinary and interdisciplinary research that is theoretically grounded and addresses significant scientific and societal challenges.

title: Human Networks and Data Science
summary_text: The Human Networks and Data Science program (HNDS) focuses on enhancing the understanding of human behavior through data and network science across various topics. It emphasizes the development of data resources and analytic techniques to support social, behavioral, and economic research, as well as advancing theoretical frameworks in these disciplines using large, diverse datasets and network analysis methods. The program aims to generate insights that can lead to improved health, prosperity, and security, while fostering innovative research that leverages existing NSF-supported data infrastructures.

title: Plasma Physics
summary_text: The Plasma Physics program invites research proposals focused on the fundamental principles governing plasma behavior, particularly through collective interactions of charged particles. Key research topics include magnetized plasmas, high energy density plasmas, low temperature plasmas, dusty and ultra-cold plasmas, non-neutral plasmas, and intense field-matter interactions. The program also emphasizes the importance of diversity in the plasma physics community and encourages the development of educational curricula related to plasma physics.

title: Cognitive Neuroscience
summary_text: The Cognitive Neuroscience (CogNeuro) program focuses on advancing the understanding of neural mechanisms related to human cognition and behavior. Key research topics include perception, memory (implicit and explicit), attention, language, decision-making, and social reasoning, utilizing a variety of physiological methods such as neuroimaging, non-invasive stimulation, and computational modeling. Proposals should aim for convergence across multiple techniques and must establish a clear link between behavior and physiology, while also addressing broader impacts through outreach and mentoring initiatives.

title: SPURRING PROJECTS TO ADVANCE ENERGY RESEARCH AND KNOWLEDGE SWIFTLY (SPARKS)
summary_text: The ARPA-E Funding Opportunity Announcement focuses on transformative research and development in energy technologies aimed at enhancing U.S. economic and energy security. Key research topics include the reduction of energy imports, lowering energy-related emissions, improving energy efficiency across sectors, and developing innovative solutions for radioactive waste management. The agency seeks projects that can create new learning curves for energy technologies, potentially leading to disruptive market innovations.

title: ECosystem for Leading Innovation in Plasma Science and Engineering
summary_text: The ECLIPSE program focuses on advancing plasma science through interdisciplinary research that addresses societal and technological challenges. Key research topics include plasma surface interactions, atmospheric pressure and microplasmas, dusty plasmas, novel sensor and computational modeling development, studies of plasmons in nano-photonics, and chemical measurement science related to plasmas. The program aims to foster collaboration across multiple NSF Directorates and enhance workforce development in STEM fields related to plasma science and engineering.

title: NRL Long Range Broad Agency Announcement (BAA) for Basic and Applied Research
summary_text: The Naval Research Laboratory is seeking innovative research proposals that focus on advancing technical topics relevant to their mission. The proposals should demonstrate potential for improvement in specified areas, with an emphasis on scientific merit and technical approaches. Interested parties, including educational institutions and small businesses, are encouraged to submit White Papers outlining their research ideas.

title: Probability
summary_text: The Probability Program focuses on research in the theory and applications of probability, encompassing areas such as discrete probability, stochastic processes, limit theory, interacting particle systems, and Markov processes. It particularly encourages studies that apply probability concepts to other scientific and engineering fields.

provider: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - ERA
title: Occupational Safety and Health Education and Research Centers (T42)
summary_text: The grant call focuses on establishing Education and Research Centers (ERCs) dedicated to training in occupational safety and health. Key research topics include industrial hygiene, occupational health nursing, occupational medicine, and occupational safety, with an emphasis on addressing issues outlined in the NIOSH National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA) and emerging challenges in the field. ERCs aim to enhance workforce development and collaboration across various sectors to improve worker health, safety, and well-being.

provider: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - ERA
title: Occupational Safety and Health Training Project Grants (T03)
summary_text: The grant call focuses on training projects aimed at enhancing occupational safety and health (OSH) education and workforce development. Key research topics include the development of academic programs at various educational levels in OSH disciplines, as well as specialized training initiatives for specific target audiences to strengthen the nation's OSH workforce capacity.

title: Notice of Intent (NOI) related to "HARMONY: Human-Centric Analytics for Resilient & Modernized Power sYstems”
summary_text: The key research topics for the upcoming funding opportunity focus on enhancing grid reliability and resilience through human-centric analytics. The scientific emphasis is on quantifying and communicating risks and uncertainties to improve decision-making and understanding of cascading failures in modernized power systems.

title: SEEDING CRITICAL ADVANCES FOR LEADING ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES WITH UNTAPPED POTENTIAL (SCALEUP) READY
summary_text: The ARPA-E SCALEUP Ready program focuses on supporting innovative energy research and development (R&D) that aims to scale promising technologies previously funded by ARPA-E. Key research topics include the development of transformative energy technologies that enhance economic and energy security, reduce energy-related emissions, improve energy efficiency, and address the management of radioactive waste. The program emphasizes pre-commercial scaling projects that validate manufacturability, reliability, and integration of new energy technologies into broader systems, ultimately aiming to prevent stranded technologies and enhance U.S. competitiveness in global energy markets.

title: Applied Mathematics
summary_text: The Applied Mathematics program focuses on research that addresses problems in science and engineering through innovative mathematical approaches. It encourages projects that not only advance mathematical knowledge but also have significant practical applications, while promoting the training of junior applied mathematicians through research involvement. Proposals can be submitted by individual researchers or interdisciplinary teams.

title: Fire Science Innovations through Research and Education
summary_text: The FIRE program focuses on advancing research and education in wildland fire through innovative, multidisciplinary approaches. Key research topics include the development of next-generation fire models to improve predictive capabilities, enhancing resilience in the wildland-urban interface through community adaptation and infrastructure strategies, and fostering collaborative networks to synthesize knowledge and address gaps in wildland fire science. Emphasis is placed on integrating diverse perspectives and methodologies, including data collection, modeling, and community engagement, to better understand and manage the complexities of wildland fire dynamics.

title: FY25 Naval Air Warfare Center Aircraft Division Office-Wide Broad Agency Announcement
summary_text: The NAWCAD is seeking white papers for Research and Development projects that focus on advancing and improving operational capabilities within the division. Key research topics may include innovative technologies, methodologies, and processes that enhance aircraft systems and operations.

title: FY 2026 Continuation of Solicitation for the Office of Science Financial Assistance Program
summary_text: The key research topics and scientific focus areas include Advanced Scientific Computing Research, Basic Energy Sciences, Biological and Environmental Research, Fusion Energy Sciences, High Energy Physics, Nuclear Physics, and Isotope Research and Development and Production. Proposals may encompass any research aligned with the Department of Energy's Congressionally authorized mission within these areas.

title: Improving Efficiency, Reliability, and Flexibility of Coal-Based Power Plants
summary_text: The key research topics for this funding opportunity focus on the strategic refurbishment and retrofit of existing coal power plants. The aim is to develop and validate technologies that enhance the efficiency, effectiveness, and environmental performance of coal and natural gas systems, ensuring they can provide reliable and affordable electricity while supporting energy security and emissions reduction goals.

title: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) – Mines & Metals Capacity Expansion – Piloting Byproduct Critical Minerals and Materials Recovery at Domestic Industrial Facilities
summary_text: The key research topics of this NOFO focus on the extraction and production of critical material byproducts from existing industrial processes in sectors such as mining, mineral processing, power generation, and fossil fuels. The initiative aims to enhance the domestic supply of essential minerals and address vulnerabilities in the U.S. mineral supply chain.
